channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

Transport and inhibition mechanisms of human VMAT2

SlyB encapsulates outer membrane proteins in stress-induced lipid nanodomains

item.title: Dirty air is linked to smaller babies across huge swathes of Asia and Africa
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03808-7

Exposure to high levels of ozone causes mothers in low- and middle-income countries to give birth to infants with a low birth weight.
item.dc:title: Dirty air is linked to smaller babies across huge swathes of Asia and Africa

item.title: Star-struck: living my childhood dream as an astronomer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03900-y

Sthabile Kolwa uses data from South Africa’s MeerKAT telescope to shed light on black holes and how the Universe evolves.
item.dc:title: Star-struck: living my childhood dream as an astronomer
item.dc:creator: Linda Nordling

item.title: Wee VR googles give mice a true immersive experience
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03806-9

Headset could make it easier to study reactions in the animals’ brains to simulated situations.
item.dc:title: Wee VR googles give mice a true immersive experience

item.title: Earth is warming but Mount Everest is getting chillier
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03805-w

Winds triggered by climate change sweep cold air down from the summit of Mount Everest and other Himalayan peaks, leading to a cooling trend.
item.dc:title: Earth is warming but Mount Everest is getting chillier

item.title: The unsung geniuses who uncovered why we sleep and dream
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03864-z

Just 100 years ago, we understood astoundingly little about sleep and dreaming. A tight-knit band of researchers changed things, against sometimes considerable odds.
item.dc:title: The unsung geniuses who uncovered why we sleep and dream
item.dc:creator: Jennifer L. Martin

item.title: Were Neanderthals soulful inventors or strange cannibals?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03862-1

To understand the true otherness of Neanderthals, researchers must rethink the meaning they give to their archaeological finds, argues a new book.
item.dc:title: Were Neanderthals soulful inventors or strange cannibals?
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Wragg Sykes

item.title: ‘Biocomputer’ combines lab-grown brain tissue with electronic hardware
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03975-7

A system that integrates brain cells into a hybrid machine can carry out tasks such as voice recognition.
item.dc:title: ‘Biocomputer’ combines lab-grown brain tissue with electronic hardware
item.dc:creator: Lilly Tozer

item.title: Is cannabis bad for teens? Here’s what the data say
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03860-3

Ten years after cannabis was first legalized for casual use in adults, scientists are struggling to provide evidence-based recommendations about the risks to young people.
item.dc:title: Is cannabis bad for teens? Here’s what the data say
item.dc:creator: Anil Oza

item.title: Surge in number of ‘extremely productive’ authors concerns scientists
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03865-y

Some researchers publish a new paper every five days, on average. Data trackers suspect not all their manuscripts were produced through honest labour.
item.dc:title: Surge in number of ‘extremely productive’ authors concerns scientists
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: The best science images of 2023 — Nature’s picks
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03872-z

Cosmic dust, microscopic syrup, a flying gecko and more.
item.dc:title: The best science images of 2023 — Nature’s picks
item.dc:creator: Emma Stoye
Nisha Gaind
Katharine Sanderson
Carissa Wong

item.title: How CRISPR gene editing could help treat Alzheimer’s
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03931-5

Some researchers hoping that gene-editing technology can conquer forms of Alzheimer’s caused by genetic mutations.
item.dc:title: How CRISPR gene editing could help treat Alzheimer’s
item.dc:creator: Tosin Thompson

item.title: Publisher Correction: Spatial atlas of the mouse central nervous system at molecular resolution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06920-w

Publisher Correction: Spatial atlas of the mouse central nervous system at molecular resolution
item.dc:title: Publisher Correction: Spatial atlas of the mouse central nervous system at molecular resolution

item.title: Powerful X-ray reveals the inner life of an electric-vehicle battery
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03756-2

Researchers get an unprecedented glimpse of how ions behave during a drive.
item.dc:title: Powerful X-ray reveals the inner life of an electric-vehicle battery

item.title: The low carbon cost of alleviating poverty
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03964-w

New modeling study suggests that reducing global poverty does not have to derail decarbonization efforts
item.dc:title: The low carbon cost of alleviating poverty
item.dc:creator: Alex Lathbridge

item.title: Mini fat particles help to turn platelets into protein factories
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03753-5

Genetically modified blood cells could churn out therapeutic proteins for treating inflammation and other conditions.
item.dc:title: Mini fat particles help to turn platelets into protein factories

item.title: My brief appearance in Downton Abbey: Nature readers share stories of side gigs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03942-2

From rugby refereeing to film and television work, a poll reveals scientists’ first jobs and what they learnt from them.
item.dc:title: My brief appearance in Downton Abbey: Nature readers share stories of side gigs
item.dc:creator: Jop de Vrieze

item.title: Time crystal
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03895-6

Murder most horrid.
item.dc:title: Time crystal
item.dc:creator: Andrew Spielberg

item.title: Daily briefing: ‘Tweezers’ hold quantum molecule
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03971-x

A breakthrough quantum-computing approach uses single molecules as qubits for the first time. Plus, in vitro embryo models are the method of the year and what’s next for CRISPR after landmark approvals.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: ‘Tweezers’ hold quantum molecule
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Massive shake-up of French science system is biggest in decades
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03957-9

Billion-euro plan includes greater oversight for national research institutes and the creation of a top-level council to advise the president on science.
item.dc:title: Massive shake-up of French science system is biggest in decades
item.dc:creator: Barbara Casassus

item.title: Why we need an academic career path that combines science and art
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03394-8

Researchers who are as skilled in the studio as they are in the lab are forced to choose between disciplines.
item.dc:title: Why we need an academic career path that combines science and art
item.dc:creator: Julie Gould

item.title: Eat less meat: Will the first global climate deal on food work?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03960-0

The first global declaration on reducing the eye-watering emissions from food production is a start, say researchers – but sidesteps some of the most contentious issues.
item.dc:title: Eat less meat: Will the first global climate deal on food work?
item.dc:creator: Carissa Wong

item.title: How to slay your zombies
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03958-8

Triaging undead research projects and learning to move on.
item.dc:title: How to slay your zombies
item.dc:creator: A. R. Siders
Nicola Ulibarri
Amanda E. Cravens
Rebecca L. Nelson

item.title: The world’s largest proteins? These mega-molecules turn bacteria into predators
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03937-z

A candidate for the largest known protein might help killer aquatic bacteria to devour other microbes — but it’s not easy to study the behemoths, or prove they’re even real.
item.dc:title: The world’s largest proteins? These mega-molecules turn bacteria into predators
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: Holiday side dish: a big helping of indoor air pollution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03754-4

Particulate-matter levels in US homes peak during mealtime — and especially on Thanksgiving and Christmas.
item.dc:title: Holiday side dish: a big helping of indoor air pollution

item.title: Why coffee particles clump and make a mess during grinding
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03755-3

Scientists studying the electrical charge on coffee particles stumble on a secret to a better cup of joe.
item.dc:title: Why coffee particles clump and make a mess during grinding

item.title: Daily briefing: Organs that look old before their time are linked to disease risk
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03947-x

Your major organs can age at different rates — and organs that look old before their time are linked to disease risk. Plus, sisal menstrual pads show the power of ‘frugal innovation’ and the first self-amplifying RNA vaccine wins full regulatory approval.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Organs that look old before their time are linked to disease risk
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: This cyborg cockroach could be the future of earthquake search and rescue
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03801-0

From drivable bionic animals to machines made from muscle, biohybrid robots are on their way to a variety of uses.
item.dc:title: This cyborg cockroach could be the future of earthquake search and rescue
item.dc:creator: Liam Drew

item.title: NIH researchers vote to form a union for the first time
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03898-3

The new bargaining group will represent thousands of early-career scientists at the US National Institutes of Health.
item.dc:title: NIH researchers vote to form a union for the first time
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: Quantum-computing approach uses single molecules as qubits for first time
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03943-1

Platforms based on molecules manipulated using ‘optical tweezers’ might be able to perform complex physics calculations.
item.dc:title: Quantum-computing approach uses single molecules as qubits for first time
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: CRISPR 2.0: a new wave of gene editors heads for clinical trials
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03797-7

Landmark approval of the first CRISPR therapy paves the way for treatments based on more efficient and more precise genome editors.
item.dc:title: CRISPR 2.0: a new wave of gene editors heads for clinical trials
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: Big Bang observatory tops wish list for big US physics projects
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03944-0

Report also supports projects of unprecedented scale to study dark matter, neutrinos and the Higgs boson.
item.dc:title: Big Bang observatory tops wish list for big US physics projects
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Women who travel boost research networks at home — but only in countries with high gender equity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03932-4

Researchers moving between institutions in low- and middle-income countries can confer wide-reaching benefits on their colleagues.
item.dc:title: Women who travel boost research networks at home — but only in countries with high gender equity
item.dc:creator: Natasha Gilbert

item.title: Author Correction: CD201<sup>+</sup> fascia progenitors choreograph injury repair
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06928-2

Author Correction: CD201+ fascia progenitors choreograph injury repair
item.dc:title: Author Correction: CD201<sup>+</sup> fascia progenitors choreograph injury repair

Logical quantum processor based on reconfigurable atom arrays

item.title: The world’s smallest light-trapping silicon cavity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03886-7

Researchers exploit intermolecular forces to carve a nanoscale hole, and investigating whether poverty can be reduced without increasing emissions.
item.dc:title: The world’s smallest light-trapping silicon cavity
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe
Shamini Bundell

item.title: This bird escaped extinction — but its genes hint at an ominous future
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03752-6

The extravagantly feathered Seychelles paradise flycatcher lacks genetic diversity, which might hamper its resilience to climate change and other threats.
item.dc:title: This bird escaped extinction — but its genes hint at an ominous future

item.title: How immense mountains create one of the rainiest places on Earth
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03758-0

The western coast of Colombia can get more than 26 metres of rain a year, thanks to the influence of air jets hitting the Andes range.
item.dc:title: How immense mountains create one of the rainiest places on Earth

item.title: Bipolar outflows out to 10 kpc for massive galaxies at redshift z ≈ 1
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06718-w

An ultra-deep MUSE image of the mean Mg II emission for a sample of galaxies at redshift z ≈ 1 suggests the presence of bipolar outflows on scales of 10 kpc or more.
item.dc:title: Bipolar outflows out to 10 kpc for massive galaxies at redshift z ≈ 1

item.title: N1-methylpseudouridylation of mRNA causes +1 ribosomal frameshifting
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06800-3

A study demonstrates that nucleotide modifications in mRNA-based therapeutics can lead to +1 ribosomal frameshifting during translation, yielding products that can trigger immune responses.
item.dc:title: N1-methylpseudouridylation of mRNA causes +1 ribosomal frameshifting
item.dc:creator: Thomas E. Mulroney

item.title: A novel antidiuretic hormone governs tumour-induced renal dysfunction
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06833-8

Experiments using conserved tumour models show that the G-protein-coupled receptor TkR99D in Drosophila Malphigian tubular stellate cells and NK3R in mouse renal tubules link malignant tumours to defective excretory functions.
item.dc:title: A novel antidiuretic hormone governs tumour-induced renal dysfunction
item.dc:creator: Wenhao Xu
Gerui Li
Yuan Chen
Xujun Ye
Wei Song

item.title: Biological carbon pump estimate based on multidecadal hydrographic data
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06772-4

By using several decades of hydrographic data and an inverse biogeochemical model that implicitly accounts for all known export pathways, a top-down estimate of the strength of the biological carbon pump is calculated.
item.dc:title: Biological carbon pump estimate based on multidecadal hydrographic data
item.dc:creator: Wei-Lei Wang
Weiwei Fu
Frédéric A. C. Le Moigne
Robert T. Letscher
Yi Liu
Jin-Ming Tang
François W. Primeau

item.title: A genomic mutational constraint map using variation in 76,156 human genomes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06045-0

A genomic constraint map for the human genome constructed using data from 76,156 human genomes from the Genome Aggregation Database shows that non-coding constrained regions are enriched for regulatory elements and variants associated with complex diseases and traits.
item.dc:title: A genomic mutational constraint map using variation in 76,156 human genomes

Benjamin M. Neale
Daniel G. MacArthur
Konrad J. Karczewski

item.title: TAF15 amyloid filaments in frontotemporal lobar degeneration
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06801-2

Cryogenic electron microscopy structures of amyloid filaments extracted from patient brains reveal that the protein TAF15 forms filaments that characterize certain cases of frontotemporal lobar degeneration.
item.dc:title: TAF15 amyloid filaments in frontotemporal lobar degeneration
item.dc:creator: Stephan Tetter
Diana Arseni
Alexey G. Murzin
Yazead Buhidma

Bernardino Ghetti
Benjamin Ryskeldi-Falcon

item.title: Single-molecule electron spin resonance by means of atomic force microscopy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06754-6

By using a pump–probe atomic force microscopy detection scheme, electron spin transitions between non-equilibrium triplet states of individual pentacene molecules, as well as the ability to manipulate electron spins over tens of microseconds, is demonstrated.
item.dc:title: Single-molecule electron spin resonance by means of atomic force microscopy
item.dc:creator: Lisanne Sellies
Raffael Spachtholz
Sonja Bleher
Jakob Eckrich
Philipp Scheuerer
Jascha Repp

item.title: A human embryonic limb cell atlas resolved in space and time
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06806-x

Using single-cell and spatial transcriptomics, human embryonic limb development across space and time and the diversification and cross-species conservation of cells are demonstrated.
item.dc:title: A human embryonic limb cell atlas resolved in space and time
item.dc:creator: Bao Zhang

item.title: An IL-4 signalling axis in bone marrow drives pro-tumorigenic myelopoiesis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06797-9

Single-cell transcriptomics studies on human and mouse non-small cell lung cancer and conditional knockout mouse models show that IL-4 from bone marrow basophils drives the development of granulocyte-monocyte progenitors to myeloid cells that suppress antitumour immunity.
item.dc:title: An IL-4 signalling axis in bone marrow drives pro-tumorigenic myelopoiesis
item.dc:creator: Nelson M. LaMarche

item.title: Organ aging signatures in the plasma proteome track health and disease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06802-1

Blood plasma protein data was combined with machine learning models for a simple method to determine differences in organ-specific aging; the study provides a basis for the prediction of diseases and aging effects using plasma proteomics.
item.dc:title: Organ aging signatures in the plasma proteome track health and disease
item.dc:creator: Hamilton Se-Hwee Oh

item.title: Dictionary of immune responses to cytokines at single-cell resolution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06816-9

An extensive global transcriptomics analysis of in vivo responses to 86 cytokines across more than 17 immune cell types reveals enormous complexity of cellular responses to cytokines, providing the basis of the Immune Dictionary and its companion software Immune Response Enrichment Analysis.
item.dc:title: Dictionary of immune responses to cytokines at single-cell resolution
item.dc:creator: Ang Cui
Teddy Huang
Shuqiang Li
Aileen Ma

Nir Hacohen

item.title: Self-assembled photonic cavities with atomic-scale confinement
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06736-8

Silicon photonic nanocavities based on surface forces and conventional lithography and etching are developed, demonstrating pioneering technology that integrates atomic dimensions with the scalability of planar semiconductors.
item.dc:title: Self-assembled photonic cavities with atomic-scale confinement
item.dc:creator: Ali Nawaz Babar

Konstantinos Tsoukalas
Shima Kadkhodazadeh

item.title: Nomad
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03824-7

Two by two.
item.dc:title: Nomad
item.dc:creator: Richard A. Lovett

item.title: US agency launches experiments to find innovative ways to fund research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03933-3

Caleb Watney explains how the National Science Foundation’s ‘science of science’ programme will find efficiencies and support ‘high-risk, high-reward’ studies.
item.dc:title: US agency launches experiments to find innovative ways to fund research
item.dc:creator: Dalmeet Singh Chawla

item.title: Probing single electron spins with an atomic force microscope for quantum applications
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03650-x

Electron spin resonance is a standard method for studying the structure of chemical compounds, and it can also be used to control quantum spin states. Combining electron spin resonance with atomic force microscopy allows single spins to be manipulated in single molecules — with potential applications in quantum computing and elsewhere.
item.dc:title: Probing single electron spins with an atomic force microscope for quantum applications

item.title: Humanity’s oldest art is flaking away. Can scientists save it?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03818-5

Ancient humans painted scenes in Indonesian caves more than 45,000 years ago, but their art is disappearing rapidly. Researchers are trying to discover what’s causing the damage and how to stop it — before the murals are gone forever.
item.dc:title: Humanity’s oldest art is flaking away. Can scientists save it?
item.dc:creator: Dyani Lewis

item.title: Catastrophic change looms as Earth nears climate ‘tipping points’, report says
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03849-y

Polar ice, coral reefs and other Earth systems could cross irrevocable thresholds soon, but urgent action could stave off the worst effects.
item.dc:title: Catastrophic change looms as Earth nears climate ‘tipping points’, report says
item.dc:creator: Jeff Tollefson

item.title: Frugal innovation: why low cost doesn’t have to mean low impact
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03816-7

Science is starting to recognize the movement to create mass-market products using local knowledge and materials to improve lives around the world.
item.dc:title: Frugal innovation: why low cost doesn’t have to mean low impact

item.title: Daily briefing: How to stave off climate tipping points with self-perpetuating solutions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03939-x

Planet-altering climate ‘tipping points’ are looming — but positive behavioural and economic shifts could result in runaway benefits for the climate. Plus, scientists race to save ancient cave paintings and how the clumsy use of AI is fuelling the reproducibility crisis.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: How to stave off climate tipping points with self-perpetuating solutions
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Self-copying RNA vaccine wins first full approval: what’s next?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03859-w

Researchers look ahead to the potential uses and benefits of a technology that has been more than 20 years in the making.
item.dc:title: Self-copying RNA vaccine wins first full approval: what’s next?
item.dc:creator: Elie Dolgin

item.title: Harmful tumour–kidney interactions identified
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03630-1

Fatal renal dysfunction is often associated with tumour development. Fly and mouse data reveal evolutionarily conserved mechanisms that link tumours to renal failure and offer potential for future therapeutic approaches.
item.dc:title: Harmful tumour–kidney interactions identified
item.dc:creator: Pierre Leopold

item.title: An expanded genomic database for identifying disease-related variants
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01598-6

An expanded version of a human-genome database called gnomAD, containing 76,156 whole-genome sequences, has enabled investigation of how variants in non-protein-coding regions of the genome affect health.
item.dc:title: An expanded genomic database for identifying disease-related variants
item.dc:creator: Ryan S. Dhindsa
Slavé Petrovski

item.title: India and climate: what does the world’s most populous nation want from COP28?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03866-x

India wants to be the voice of the global south at the climate conference. It is also massively dependent on coal.
item.dc:title: India and climate: what does the world’s most populous nation want from COP28?
item.dc:creator: Gayathri Vaidyanathan

item.title: Are your organs ageing well? The blood holds clues
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03821-w

One organ in a person’s body can age faster than the rest — with implications for health and mortality.
item.dc:title: Are your organs ageing well? The blood holds clues
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: Self-assembling structures close the gap to trap light
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03685-0

An innovative method uses the intrinsic attractive force between silicon surfaces that are separated by a tiny gap to engineer structures that can confine light — offering an ideal set-up for manipulating single photons.
item.dc:title: Self-assembling structures close the gap to trap light
item.dc:creator: Takashi Asano

Hypoblast from human pluripotent stem cells regulates epiblast development

item.title: Forecast warns when sea life will get tangled in nets — one year in advance
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03870-1

Computational model uses sea-surface temperatures to predict when whales and turtles are likely to get stuck in fishing gear.
item.dc:title: Forecast warns when sea life will get tangled in nets — one year in advance
item.dc:creator: Carissa Wong

item.title: Broaden scope of review boards to boost public trust
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03856-z

Broaden scope of review boards to boost public trust
item.dc:title: Broaden scope of review boards to boost public trust
item.dc:creator: Daniel Wyzynski

item.title: Brain implants help people to recover after severe head injury
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02833-w

Electrodes placed inside the brains of five people with traumatic injuries improved recipients’ performance in attention and memory tests.
item.dc:title: Brain implants help people to recover after severe head injury
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf
